bill_title: to limit the number of court-appointed attorneys and experts and the amount of money that can be paid to them for an indigent criminal defendant.

bill_versions.bill_text: FOR AN ACT ENTITLED, An Act to limit the number of court-appointed attorneys and experts and the amount of money that can be paid to them for an indigent criminal defendant. BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA: Section 1. That chapter 23A-40 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: Notwithstanding the provisions of § 23A-40-6, no court may assign more than one attorney for an indigent defendant in any criminal case unless the state is seeking the death sentence. If the state is seeking the death sentence, the court may assign as many as two attorneys to represent an indigent defendant. Nothing in this section may be construed by the court to limit the prosecution's ability to carry its burden through the use of prosecuting attorneys. Section 2. That chapter 23A-40 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: If an assigned attorney is permitted to withdraw as counsel pursuant to § 16-18-31, the court may, within the limitations of § 23A-40-6.1, assign new counsel. Section 3. That chapter 23A-40 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: Pursuant to the provisions of § § 23A-40-8 and 23A-40-9, the presiding judge of each circuit shall establish a schedule of fees for the reasonable compensation of assigned counsel in criminal cases within that circuit. Any payments made to assigned counsel in a criminal case shall be paid in accordance with the schedule of fees. The schedule shall, at a minimum, include the following: (1) Maximum hourly rates; (2) Maximum daily rates for in-court appearances; (3) Maximum total compensation for any one criminal case except for a case in which the state is seeking the death sentence; and (4) Maximum total compensation for all appellate work, including cases in which the state is seeking the death sentence. Section 4. That chapter 23A-40 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: A circuit judge may seek approval from the presiding judge within the circuit to depart from the fee schedule. A presiding judge may allow a departure from the fee schedule if, after consultation with the circuit judge, the presiding judge finds a compelling reason to do so. Section 5. That chapter 23A-40 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: Notwithstanding the provisions of § 23A-40-9, no court may appoint more than one attorney to represent an indigent defendant in any proceeding after judgment and conviction. Section 6. That chapter 19-15 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: No expert may be appointed to assist an indigent defendant in a criminal case unless the defendant makes a preliminary showing that the field of expertise is likely to be a significant factor at trial and that an issue within that field is seriously in question. Section 7. That chapter 19-15 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: Notwithstanding the provisions of § 19-15-9, no court may appoint more than one expert for each field of expertise to assist an indigent defendant in a criminal case. Nothing in this section may be construed by the court to limit the prosecution's ability to carry its burden through the use of expert witnesses. Section 8. That chapter 19-15 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: If a court-appointed defense expert in a criminal case becomes unavailable to testify at trial, the court may, within the limitations of § 19-15-21, appoint another expert to replace the unavailable expert. Section 9. That chapter 19-15 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: Any payments made to a court-appointed expert in a criminal case shall be paid in accordance with a schedule of fees adopted by formal action of the presiding judge within each circuit. Each fee schedule shall, at a minimum, include the following: (1) Maximum hourly rates; (2) Maximum daily rates for in-court work; (3) Maximum daily rates for out-of-court work; and (4) Maximum total compensation for any one criminal case. Section 10. That chapter 19-15 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: A circuit judge may seek approval from the presiding judge within the circuit to depart from the fee schedule. A presiding judge may allow a departure from the fee schedule if, after consultation with the circuit judge, the presiding judge finds a compelling reason to do so. Section 11. That chapter 21-27 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: Notwithstanding the provisions of § 21-27-4, no court may appoint more than one attorney to represent an indigent defendant in any proceeding under this chapter.
